alert.note: Alert for Beaverhead; Blaine; Broadwater; Cascade; Chouteau; Fergus; Gallatin; Glacier; Jefferson; Judith Basin; Lewis and Clark; Liberty; Madison; Meagher; Pondera; Teton; Toole (Montana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 09 at 10:52AM MDT by NWS GreatFalls
info.description: …POTENTIAL FOR MINOR FLOODING THROUGH EARLY THIS WEEK FROM MELTING SNOWPACK… Above normal temperatures will result in rapid snowmelt of lower elevations of north-central and southwest Montana. This will result in a increased risk for flooding of lowlands and poor drainage areas, and along creeks and streams emanating from the mountains. Daytime temperatures on Sunday and Monday are forecast to climb into the upper 50s to 60s for the mid elevations and into the 70s to near 80 degrees for the valleys and plains. Note that overnight lows will also remain well above freezing in the 40s and 50s both Sunday night and Monday night, prolonging the period of snowmelt and subsequent runoff. Although temperatures will be quite warm through early this week, subsurface soil temperatures will still be below freezing, which could exacerbate flooding in low lying areas where the soil is saturated and or frozen. Temperatures will trend cooler again by Wednesday, but flooding concerns will continue through at least mid-week and possibly into late week. While flooding is not imminent, now is the time to prepare for potential flooding this week. Clear ice and debris from culverts and other flow paths to allow runoff to flow away from buildings and other vulnerable infrastructure. Check the functionality of sump pumps prior to the start of runoff to ensure proper operation and prevent basement flooding due to high groundwater levels. Move equipment, forage, and livestock out of poorly drained or low lying areas.
